item.title: Different ways to observe properties in Swift
item.description: Many programming techniques involve observing and reacting to changes in state. In Swift, we use properties to represent the state of our types. In this post, Jesse Squires provides an overview of how we can observe changes to such properties and explains why he decided not to include a mechanism for observing state in his open-source library, Foil.

item.title: Struct References
item.description: Great article from Chris Eidhof in which he looks to combine the usage of references types and value types to get the best of both worlds. He uses new Swift 4 features such as keypaths and generic subscripts together with existing Swift features to create types which are mutable and observable, while also having underlying value type data.

item.title: Key Value Observation in iOS 11
item.description: Skye Freeman with a short post reminding us that the Codable protocols are not the only exciting additions in Swift 4. Skye provides an example showcasing exactly why the new Swift syntax for key value observing is so awesome, and details some of the things we need to know when using the new syntax.
